body:
AIUI the purpose of introducing the notion of the performant subspace is so that we can say "lies on the boundary of the subspace, but not the frontier."

But I think we can simplify this for readers.  What if we said something to the effect of what you had before about the frontier, and then defined the concept of "on the frontier in the short dim but not the long dim"?  (Or is it on the long dim but not the short dim?  Anyway.)

I think that would obviate a lot of the confusion I'm having reading this patch now, where I have to keep straight the "boundary" as separate from the "frontier", even though those words are synonymous in my mind, and even though the two divisions are closely related.

WDYT?

body_text:
AIUI the purpose of introducing the notion of the performant subspace is so that we can say "lies on the boundary of the subspace, but not the frontier."
But I think we can simplify this for readers.  What if we said something to the effect of what you had before about the frontier, and then defined the concept of "on the frontier in the short dim but not the long dim"?  (Or is it on the long dim but not the short dim?  Anyway.)
I think that would obviate a lot of the confusion I'm having reading this patch now, where I have to keep straight the "boundary" as separate from the "frontier", even though those words are synonymous in my mind, and even though the two divisions are closely related.
WDYT?
